title: Attesting/Target Environments terms used before being defined
body:
Section 6 "Two Types of Environments of an Attester" gives the introduction to these terms, but they are used back in section 4.1 "Composite Attester".

Something needs to change either move section 6 up, or section 4.1 down.

title: The second paragraph of section 7 seems no very clear to me:
body: It seems to me the statement applies for both models (passport model and BC model).

title: It seems to miss a final conclusion for the second paragragh in section 5.1
body:
Since the resource access protocol between the Attester and Relying
Party includes an Attestation Result, in this model the details of
that protocol constrain the serialization format of the Attestation
Result. The format of the Evidence on the other hand is only
constrained by the Attester-Verifier attestation protocol. "So..."

title: In Section 5.2, "security policy" should be "apprisal policy"
In Section 5.1, is it approriate to say that the attestation result is success or failure?
body:
The more accurate text should be compliance or non-compliance.
And whatever the attestation result is, the attester should always present the attestation result to the relying party, I think.

title: Can TPM be the attesting enviroment? In Section 4.1
body:
I don't think so, since it's just the RoTS and RoTR, but not the RoTM.
Opinions?

title: should the concept of nested composite attester be considered or discussed in current document, like in section 4.1?
move section 6 before section 4.1
body:
otherwise,  the section 4.1 including a lot of content about attester, attesting enviroment and target enviroment are not easy to understand.
Or, at least, have some general introduction or reference to section 6 about what is relation between them.

title: figure 2 --- device or other name for outer box
body: What should the label on the outer box be: Device or Composite Device or Attester or ...?

title: diagram updated to remove word Composite Attester
body:
Diagram updated, now uses Attester rather than Composite Attester.
Could use the word "Device" rather than Attester.

title: new term: "Composite Attester"
Added a rather elaborate example on how Layered Attestion could take place.
body: Please feel free to bash. This is a basis for discussion.

title: Add ASCII version of Ned's layered attester diagram
body: Signed-off-by: Dave Thaler <dthaler@microsoft.com>

title: Lead Attester may be evaluated first than other Attesters
body: For the situation that the Lead Attester has an internal Verifier, the Lead Attester may need to be evaluated first before it receives the Endorsements and Appraisal Policy of other Attesters. This is also a security enhancement.

body:
"(via Internal Links or Network Connections)" is ambiguous.

Is it Internal (Links or Network Connections) or
(Internal Links) or (Network Connections)

Define Layered Attestation

title: Changes to Composite Attester section based on design team discussion
body:
This attempts to address the remaining feedback on PR #13 on issues that were not fixed before it was merged.

Signed-off-by: Dave Thaler <dthaler@microsoft.com>

title: Target should be defined in terminology section
Entity and Sub-Entity & Composite Device and Component
body:
Taking into account the recent trends in terminology used in draft text & PR, I am proposing to add Entity and Sub-Entity to the terminology section. We do not need to over-specify here. Hence, only mentioning Composite Device and Components as an examplew for each of the terms in the definition text could be enough.

Are there any objections to this proposal? If not, we could create a PR and address it in next week's meeting.

title: Claim is used heavily but not in the terminology section
Replace "measure" with "collect"
body:
Addresses issue #14
And review comments on PR #15

Signed-off-by: Dave Thaler <dthaler@microsoft.com>

title: Add strawman test about freshness
body:
Based on discussion at IETF about including a very high level summary,
and text in the arch docs, draft-birkholz-rats-reference-interaction-model,
and draft-birkholz-rats-tuda.

Signed-off-by: Dave Thaler <dthaler@microsoft.com>

title: Text for the Two Types of Environments section
body:
Incorporating text from draft-birkholz-rats-architecture
and from my reading of the "bike shed" mailing list thread

Signed-off-by: Dave Thaler <dthaler@microsoft.com>

title: introduce term "measure"
body:
Ned suggests that the term Measure be added to connect the Attested Environment and Attesting Environment.  
There may be multiple Attested Environments that can measured by a single Attesting Environment (such as when there is a TPM, SGX, DICE).

title: Describe the Composite Attester Data Flow
body: This is a preliminary description of the remote attestation of composite attester

title: minor update of the term 'Appraisal Policy for Attestation Result'
body: When comparing the term 'Appraisal Policy for Evidence' and 'Appraisal Policy for Attestation Result', they are both saying 'evaluates the validity of information about an Attester'. This makes me feel Verifier and Relying Party are doing the same things and they are redundant. I think it's more appropriate to say that the Relying Party evaluates the evaluation results generated by the Verifiers.

title: Editorial cleanup regarding Remote Attestation term
body:
Removed incorrect text that said Remote Attestation was not defined in the doc.

Moved Remote Attestation paragraph to the introduction section where I think it will (eventually) make sense in the context of introduction text.

Signed-off-by: Dave Thaler <dthaler@microsoft.com>

title: Add topological models text from the Thaler and Birkholz docs
body: Signed-off-by: Dave Thaler <dthaler@microsoft.com>

title: should architecture define "Attestation"
body:
See comments in https://github.com/ietf-rats-wg/architecture/pull/6

this term gets re-introduced here, without any annotation.
The appraisal policy are the rules on how to test the evidence.
Here, "Attestation" is the creation of the evidence
Often people use the term "Attestation" to refer to the whole process.
Suggestion that we should define this term somewhere, but maybe "Remote Attestation"?

@mcr
FIDO has NONE-Attestation-Type, where there is no assessment. TCG would call this Implicit Attestation. https://www.w3.org/TR/webauthn/#none-attestation

 @mcr
Let's take this to the WG, and maybe we can not get consensus on this term.

 @mcr
Charter says: "Remote
attestation procedures (RATS) enable relying parties to establish a level of
confidence in the trustworthiness of remote system components through the
creation of attestation evidence by remote system components and a processing
chain towards the relying party."
